awd_titl_txt: HDR DSC: Collaborative Research: The Data Science WAV: Experiential Learning with Local Community Organizations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project simultaneously addresses two problems: 1) the inability of community-based and non-profit organizations to tackle data science problems; and 2) the lack of real world experience gained by students studying data science. The increased availability of data, combined with increased computing power at lower costs, has brought to the desktop tremendous analytical and problem solving capabilities. Yet many organizations are not able to take advantage of these developments because they often lack appropriate staffing to wrestle with complex data science problems. Meanwhile, as students increasingly gravitate toward data science programs, much of their course-based problem solving experience focuses on clean problems with simple data sets. This leaves them unprepared for the reality of the data science applications they will face in professional settings. This project addresses both issues by deploying teams of data science students to assist local organizations, thereby increasing the long-term capacity of the data science workforce.

This is a multifaceted project that will provide immediate impact to local organizations and long-term benefit for students through valuable hands-on data science experience. There are two major components of the proposed project. First, Data Science WAV teams of four specially-trained undergraduate students will be deployed to community-based organizations to Wrangle, Analyze, and Visualize their data. Second, this project will offer summer faculty development workshops designed to help new instructors, especially those at community colleges, teach data science at their institutions. Curricular innovations that bring experiential data science learning into the curriculum will lead to sustained impact at the partnering academic institutions and in the larger Pioneer Valley region. This proposal is diverse across both institutions and student populations. It comprises one major research university (The University of Massachusetts, Amherst), four liberal arts colleges (Amherst, Hampshire, Mount Holyoke, and Smith), and three local community colleges (Greenfield, Holyoke, and Springfield Technical). The inclusion of two women's colleges (Smith and Mount Holyoke) and two Hispanic-serving institutions (Holyoke and Springfield Technical) will help ensure that a diverse student population is engaged in the project. 

NSF's Harnessing the Data Revolution Data Science Corps program focuses on building capacity for harnessing the data revolution at the local, state, national, and international levels to help unleash the power of data in the service of science and society. Projects in this program are being jointly funded by the NSF's Harnessing the Data Revolution Big Idea; the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering, Division of Information and Intelligent Systems; the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education; the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, Division of Mathematical Sciences; and the Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences, Office of Multidisciplinary Activities and Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
In 2019, with support from the National Science Foundation (NSF) Award #1922982 The Data Science WAV: Experiential Learning with Local Community Organizations was granted.  Springfield Technical Community College, STCC, participated with the lead institutions of Amherst College and Smith College.

The focus was to increase long-term data science capacity in the Pioneer Valley area of Western Massachusetts, while also providing students with valuable hands-on data science experience. The two components of the project were:

1. Data Science WAV teams: specially trained teams of four undergraduate students who that are deployed to community based organizations to Wrangle, Analyze, and visualize their data.

2.Summer Faculty Development Workshops designed to help new instructors - especially those at community colleges - teach data science at their institutions, using curricular innovations that bring experiential data science learning into the community college curriculum.

The grant was originally scheduled to run from 2020 – 2022.  With additional funds left over due to the COVID-19 pandemic the co-PI and STCC’s Grants Department applied for and was granted a one-year extension to the year 2023.   

STCC is happy to report we have exceed out initials expectations and we accomplished the following during the lifespan of this grant:

-STCC Faculty got introductory training using the RStudio software.

-STCC Faculty got introductory training using Python’s Pandas and Numpy packages.

- Recruited 6 STCC professors within the Computer Technologies and Office Information Departments to attend the DSC-WAV in person training at Smith College June 2021.  Each of the 6 teaching resources will be implementing a Data Science module and a new assignment in a course of their choosing for the 2021-2022 Academic Year.

- For the 2021-2022 Academic Year the creation of  two data science modules in the CIT-115/115L Python coding class to expose students to the introductory concepts of data science.

- Recruited 10 STCC professors within the Computer Technologies, Office Information Departments and Mathematics departments to attend the DSC-WAV in person training at Smith College June 2022. Each of the teaching resources will be implementing a Data Science module and a new assignment in a course of their choosing for the 2022-2023 Academic Year.

-Creation of a Data Analytics degree/concentration proposal was created and presented to the VP of Academic Affairs, Dean of STEM and Dean of Curricula on November 20, 2023.

In that document, three new classes and three pathways to launch a Data Analytics major/minor were proposed:

1.Create three new Data Analytics focused classes

2.Launch a new and standalone Data Analytics Associates Degree using existing and the 3 newly created courses.

3.Include a minor in the Programmer PROG.AS degree by allowing the students to choose the 3 newly created classes.

4.Launch new and standalone Data Analytics Certificate of Completion using existing and the 3 newly created courses.

We are now waiting on final approval for the proposed curricula enhancements from administration.

 In conclusion, This grant has been very rewarding to both STCC and the participants.  It has allowed us to learn about Data Science topics, best practices and the importance of this in our Knowledge Corridor from Springfield MA down to Hartford CT.   Sixteen faculty from STCC have participated in training and most have included a Data Science module within their classes.


Last Modified: 12/30/2023
Modified by: Brian Candido
